py_pg_tools.backer module¶

class py_pg_tools.backer.Backer(connecter=None, bkp_path='', group='', bkp_type='dump', prefix='', in_dbs=[], in_regex='', in_priority=False, ex_dbs=['postgres'], ex_regex='', ex_templates=True, vacuum=True, db_owner='', logger=None)¶

Bases: builtins.object

backup_db(dbname, bkps_dir)¶
Target:
  • make a backup of a specified database.
Parameters:
  • dbname: name of the database which is going to be backuped.
  • bkps_dir: directory where the backup is going to be stored.
Return:
  • a boolean which indicates the success of the process.
backup_dbs(dbs_all)¶
Target:
  • make a backup of some specified databases.
Parameters:
  • dbs_all: names of the databases which are going to be backuped.

Parameters:
  • bkps_dir: directory where the backup is going to be stored.
Return:
  • a boolean which indicates the success of the process.

  • vacuum if necessary and make a backup of a cluster.

py_pg_tools.configurator module¶

class py_pg_tools.configurator.Configurator¶

Bases: builtins.object

cfg_type = None¶
load_cfg(cfg_type, path, logger=None)¶
Target:
  • store a config parser with the obtained variables.
Parameters:
  • cfg_type: the type of config file which is going to be loaded.
  • path: the path of the config file to be loaded.
  • logger: the logger which will be show and log the messages. It will be None if the config file to load is for the logger configuration.
logger = None¶
parser = None¶
path = None¶

py_pg_tools.connecter module¶

class py_pg_tools.connecter.Connecter(server, user, port, logger=None)¶

Bases: builtins.object

This class manages connections with database engines and operations involving them. So far, only PostgreSQL is supported.

PG_PID_VERSION_THRESHOLD = 90200¶
allow_db_conn(dbname)¶
Target:
  • enable connections to a specified PostgreSQL database.
Parameters:
  • dbname: name of the database whose property “datallowconn” is going to be changed to allow connections to itself.
conn = None¶
cursor = None¶
disallow_db_conn(dbname)¶
Target:
  • disable connections to a specified PostgreSQL database.
Parameters:
  • dbname: name of the database whose property “datallowconn” is going to be changed to disallow connections to itself.
get_cursor_dbs(ex_templates=True, db_owner='')¶
Target:
  • do different queries to PostgreSQL depending on the parameters received, and store the results in the connection cursor.
Parameters:
  • ex_templates: flag which determinates whether or not get those databases which are templates.
  • db_owner: the name of the user whose databases are going to be obtained.
get_pg_conn_data(connpid)¶
Target:
  • show some info about backends.
Parameters:
  • connpid: PID of the backend whose information is going to be shown.
get_pg_connpids()¶
Target:
  • get PostgreSQL backends’ PIDs.
get_pg_db_data(dbname)¶
Target:
  • show some info about a specified database.
Parameters:
  • dbname: name of the database whose information is going to be shown.
get_pg_dbnames(ex_templates=False)¶
Target:
  • get PostgreSQL databases’ names depending on the parameters received, and store the results in the connection cursor.
Parameters:
  • ex_templates: flag which determinates whether or not get those databases which are templates.
get_pg_time_start()¶
Target:
  • get the time when PostgreSQL was started.
Return:
  • a date which indicates the time when PostgreSQL was started.
get_pg_time_up()¶
Target:
  • get how long PostgreSQL has been working.
Return:
  • a date which indicates how long PostgreSQL has been working.
get_pg_user_data(username)¶
Target:
  • show some info about a specified user.
Parameters:
  • username: name of the user whose information is going to be shown.
get_pg_usernames()¶
Target:
  • get PostgreSQL users’ names.
get_pg_version()¶
Target:
  • get the PostgreSQL version.
Return:
  • a integer which gives the PostgreSQL version.
get_pid_str()¶
Target:
  • get the name of the process id depending on the PostgreSQL version which is being used. Before the version 9.2 this variable was called “procpid”, afterwards became “pid”.
Return:
  • a string which gives the name of the vaiable process id.
get_pretty_pg_version()¶
Target:
  • get the pretty PostgreSQL version.
Return:
  • a string which gives the PostgreSQL version and more details.
is_pg_superuser()¶
Target:
  • check if a user connected to PostgreSQL has a superuser role.
Return:
  • a boolean which indicates whether a user is a PostgreSQL superuser or not.
logger = None¶
pg_disconnect()¶
Target:
  • disconnect from PostgreSQL.
pg_pid_91 = 'procpid'¶
pg_pid_92 = 'pid'¶
port = None¶
server = None¶
user = None¶

py_pg_tools.orchestrator module¶

class py_pg_tools.orchestrator.Orchestrator(action, args)¶

Bases: builtins.object

action = None¶
args = []¶
detect_module()¶
Target:
  • call the corresponding function to the action stored.
static get_cfg_vars(config_type, config_path, logger=None)¶
Target:
  • get all the variables stored in a config file with cfg extension.
Parameters:
  • config_type: the type of config file which is going to be loaded, to differ it from the other types which will have different sections and variables.
  • logger: a logger to show and log some messages.
Return:
  • the parser which will contain all the config file variables.
get_cl_backer(connecter)¶
Target:
  • get a backer object with variables to backup databases’ clusters.
Parameters:
  • connecter: an object with connection parameters to connect to PostgreSQL.
Return:
  • a backer which will backup databases’ clusters.
get_cl_restorer(connecter)¶
Target:
  • get a restorer object with variables to restore a cluster backup in PostgreSQL.
Parameters:
  • connecter: an object with connection parameters to connect to PostgreSQL.
Return:
  • a restorer which will restore a PostgreSQL cluster.
get_cl_trimmer()¶
Target:
  • get a trimmer object with its variables to delete some clusters’ backups in a selected directory.
Return:
  • a trimmer which will delete clusters’ backups.
get_connecter()¶
Target:
  • get a connecter object with its variables.
Return:
  • a connecter which will allow queries to PostgreSQL.
get_db_backer(connecter)¶
Target:
  • get a backer object with variables to backup databases.
Parameters:
  • connecter: an object with connection parameters to connect to PostgreSQL.
Return:
  • a backer which will backup databases.
get_db_restorer(connecter)¶
Target:
  • get a restorer object with variables to restore a database backup in PostgreSQL.
Parameters:
  • connecter: an object with connection parameters to connect to PostgreSQL.
Return:
  • a restorer which will restore a PostgreSQL database.
get_db_trimmer()¶
Target:
  • get a trimmer object with its variables to delete some databases’ backups in a selected directory.
Return:
  • a trimmer which will delete databases’ backups.
get_dropper(connecter)¶
Target:
  • get a dropper object with variables to drop some PostgreSQL databases.
Parameters:
  • connecter: an object with connection parameters to connect to PostgreSQL.
Return:
  • a dropper which will delete some PostgreSQL databases.
get_informer(connecter)¶
Target:
  • get an informer object with variables to show some PostgreSQL information.
Parameters:
  • connecter: an object with connection parameters to connect to PostgreSQL.
Return:
  • a informer which will get and show some PostgreSQL information.
get_logger()¶
Target:
  • get a logger object with its variables.
Return:
  • a logger to show and log some messages.
get_replicator(connecter)¶
Target:
  • get a replicator object with variables to clone a PostgreSQL database.
Parameters:
  • connecter: an object with connection parameters to connect to PostgreSQL.
Return:
  • a replicator which will clone a PostgreSQL database.
get_terminator(connecter)¶
Target:
  • get a terminator object with variables to terminate connections to PostgreSQL.
Parameters:
  • connecter: an object with connection parameters to connect to PostgreSQL.
Return:
  • a terminator which will terminate connections to PostgreSQL.
get_vacuumer(connecter)¶
Target:
  • get a vacuumer object with variables to vacuum databases in PostgreSQL.
Parameters:
  • connecter: an object with connection parameters to connect to PostgreSQL.
Return:
  • a vacuumer which will vacuum PostgreSQL databases.
logger = None¶
setup_backer()¶
Target:
  • executes the backer depending on the type of backup to make, the role of the user who is connected to PostgreSQL and the rest of the conditions. It calls a terminator if necessary.
setup_dropper()¶
Target:
  • delete specified databases in PostgreSQL.
setup_informer()¶
Target:
  • give information about PostgreSQL to the user.
setup_replicator()¶
Target:
  • clone a database in PostgreSQL.
setup_restorer()¶
Target:
  • restore a specified backup file as a new database or cluster in PostgreSQL.
setup_terminator()¶
Target:
  • executes the terminator taking into account the value of its variables.
setup_trimmer()¶
Target:
  • executes the trimmer in a specified directory and delete its selected backups.
setup_vacuumer()¶
Target:
  • executes the vacuumer taking into account the value of its variables.
static show_dbs(dbs_list, logger)¶
Target:
  • show in console and log a list of databases.
Parameters:
  • dbs_list: the list of databases to be shown.
  • logger: a logger to show and log some messages.

py_pg_tools.terminator module¶

class py_pg_tools.terminator.Terminator(connecter, target_all=False, target_user='', target_dbs=, []logger=None)¶

Bases: builtins.object

connecter = None¶
logger = None¶
query_terminate_backend_all = 'SELECT pg_terminate_backend({pg_pid}) FROM pg_stat_activity WHERE {pg_pid} <> pg_backend_pid();'¶
query_terminate_backend_db = "SELECT pg_terminate_backend({pg_pid}) FROM pg_stat_activity WHERE datname = '{target_db}' AND {pg_pid} <> pg_backend_pid();"¶
query_terminate_backend_user = "SELECT pg_terminate_backend({pg_pid}) FROM pg_stat_activity WHERE usename = '{target_user}';"¶
target_all = None¶
target_dbs = []¶
target_user = None¶
terminate_backend_all()¶
Target:
  • remove every connection to PostgreSQL (except the current one).
terminate_backend_db(target_db)¶
Target:
  • terminate every connection to a PostgreSQL database (except the current one, if it is connected to the target database).
terminate_backend_dbs()¶
Target:
  • terminate every connection to some PostgreSQL databases (except the current one, if it is connected to one of the target databases).
terminate_backend_user()¶
Target:
  • terminate every connection of a specific user to PostgreSQL (as long as the target user is the one who is running the program).

py_pg_tools.trimmer module¶

class py_pg_tools.trimmer.Trimmer(bkp_path='', prefix='', in_dbs=, []in_regex='', in_priority=False, ex_dbs=, []ex_regex='', min_n_bkps=1, exp_days=365, max_size='10000MB', pg_warnings=True, connecter=None, logger=None)¶

Bases: builtins.object

bkp_path = ''¶
connecter = None¶
ex_dbs = []¶
ex_regex = ''¶
exp_days = None¶
in_dbs = []¶
in_priority = False¶
in_regex = ''¶
logger = None¶
max_size = None¶
min_n_bkps = None¶
pg_warnings = True¶
prefix = ''¶
trim_db(dbname, db_bkps_list)¶
Target:
  • remove (if necessary) some database’s backups, taking into account some parameters in the following order: minimum number of backups to keep > obsolete backups.
Parameters:
  • dbname: name of the database whose backups are going to be trimmed.
  • db_bkps_list: list of backups of a database to analyse and trim.
trim_dbs(bkps_list, dbs_to_clean)¶
Target:
  • remove (if necessary) some backups of a group of databases, taking into account some parameters in the following order: minimum number of backups to keep > obsolete backups.
Parameters:
  • bkps_list: list of backups found in the specified directory.
  • dbs_to_clean: name of the database whose backups are going to be trimmed.
class py_pg_tools.trimmer.TrimmerCluster(bkp_path='', prefix='', min_n_bkps=1, exp_days=365, max_size=5000, logger=None)¶

Bases: builtins.object

bkp_path = ''¶
exp_days = None¶
max_size = None¶
min_n_bkps = None¶
prefix = ''¶
trim_cluster(ht_bkps_list)¶
Target:
  • remove (if necessary) some cluster’s backups, taking into account some parameters in the following order: minimum number of backups to keep > obsolete backups.
Parameters:
  • ht_bkps_list: list of backups of a cluster to analyse and trim.
trim_clusters(bkps_list)¶

py_pg_tools.vacuumer module¶

class py_pg_tools.vacuumer.Vacuumer(connecter=None, in_dbs=[], in_regex='', in_priority=False, ex_dbs=['postgres'], ex_regex='', ex_templates=True, db_owner='', logger=None)¶

Bases: builtins.object

connecter = None¶
db_owner = ''¶
ex_dbs = []¶
ex_regex = ''¶
ex_templates = True¶
in_dbs = []¶
in_priority = False¶
in_regex = ''¶
logger = None¶
vacuum_db(dbname)¶
Objetivo:
  • crear una copia de seguridad de la base de datos especificada.
Parámetros:
  • logger: el logger que se empleará para mostrar y registrar el mensaje.
  • dbname: nombre de la base de datos de la que se quiere realizar una copia de seguridad.
  • conn: conexión realizada desde el script a PostgreSQL
vacuum_dbs(vacuum_list)¶
Objetivo:
  • crear copias de seguridad de las bases de datos especificadas, las que están incluidas en la variable “dbs_all”.
Parámetros:
  • logger: el logger que se empleará para mostrar y registrar el mensaje.
  • conn: conexión realizada desde el script a PostgreSQL
  • dbs_all: una lista con todos los nombres de las bases de datos de PostgreSQL de las que se desea hacer una copia de seguridad (vienen dadas por el archivo de configuración).
  • bkp_vars: diccionario con los parámetros especificados en el archivo .cfg
